item.title: Unlock the Vast Knowledge in Your Ancient DNA
item.description:
I recently discovered a secret store of untapped skill and agility that anyone can use. I was out running on a trail with no shoes on, struggling mightily not to stub my toes on all the rocks and stones. It was mentally exhausting. I'd just finished a novel: God Emperor of Dune. One of the main characters in this book has conscious access to all his ancestor's memories and experiences, encoded in his DNA.

It occurred to me that my body also contains the DNA of all of my ancestors, millions of whom probably spent a lot of time running on rugged trails. In fact, encoded into my DNA and all that has arisen out of it are the instincts of tens of millions (maybe more) organisms, not all human, that spent their entire lives navigating wild, treacherous terrain. Along the way, there must have been some creation of an instinct that helped these creatures manage rocky trails.

And, no matter how my life had progressed, I could not deny that there was in fact some remnant of all that history within me, if only in the way my DNA was constructed. The experience of my ancestors, all the way back to the first proto-life, had created the blueprint for my existence and the framework around which my brain and nervous system were built. It seemed reasonable to think that perhaps there were some useful instincts prebuilt into me.

So I decided to try something. I stopped consciously thinking about where to put my feet. I let go of the need to control my body and leaned forward to pick up speed, forcing my reflexes to direct my actions in order to avoid injury. I trusted my feet and my body's intelligence.

item.title: 3 Unexpected Benefits of Natural Movement
item.description:
When I started training with natural movements, as opposed to the contrived, isolated, and repetitive movements that used to make up the bulk of my training program, I was mainly interested in the obvious benefits: catlike reflexes, amazing strength, awe-inspiring toughness, and ninja skills.

Mostly, I was focused on the physical benefits.

But I discovered after training this way for a while that it was changing me in other ways, too. I started to relate to my body differently than I had before, even during my years training CrossFit. Instead of feeling constantly inadequate, always being a step behind where I needed to be, I started to feel capable where I was right now, even as I trained to continue improving.

I've written extensively on the physical and mental benefits of natural movement, and plenty of other people have as well, so I just wanted to share some of the less obvious benefits I've found from my training.
